Award.AwardTitle: Investigating N-mustard-based analogs of SAM as probes of biological methylation
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Lindsay Comstock from Wake Forest University to develop and investigate a novel set of biochemical tools as universal probes to identify biological methylation sites. Specifically, cellular methyltransferases facilitate transfer of synthetic N-mustard-containing analogs of S-adenosyl-L-methionine bearing azide and alkyne functionalities to their corresponding biomolecules, such as DNA and protein. Once incorporated, these functionalities can be modified through chemoselective ligation chemistries with fluorophores and affinity tags to permit both visualization in, and isolation from, complex mixtures, yielding products that can be easily characterized.

DNA and protein methyltransferases belong to a unique class of enzymes which have been well documented to play a role in key cellular functions, including metabolism and cell growth. While it has been established that DNA and protein methyltransferase activities direct a wide variety of cellular processes, the biochemical tools being developed in this project are designed to identify specific sites of biological methylation, with the ultimate goal of better understanding of methylation in cellular processes. This research will allow for undergraduate and graduate students to engage in scholarship at the interface between chemistry and biology, in collaboration with experts in biochemistry and cell biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division funded Dr. Lindsay Comstock from Wake Forest University to develop and investigate a novel set of biochemical tools as universal probes to identify biological methylation sites. DNA and protein methyltransferases belong to a unique class of enzymes which have been well documented to play a role in key cellular functions, including metabolism and cell growth. Although it has been established that DNA and protein methyltransferase activity directs a wide-variety of cellular processes, our research aimed to further advance our fundamental scientific understanding of biological methylation. The goal of our research has been to develop and investigate a novel set of chemical tools to facilitate and more effectively detect sites of biological methylation.

Specifically, we have developed N-mustard-containing analogs of S-adenosyl-L-methionine bearing azide and alkyne functionalities.  We have demonstrated that cellular methyltransferases facilitate transfer of the analog to their corresponding biomolecules, such as DNA and protein. Once incorporated on DNA and protein, we have shown that these functionalities can be modified through chemoselective ligation chemistries with fluorophores and affinity tags to permit both visualization in, and isolation from, complex mixtures, yielding products that can be easily characterized.  

The project to develop these biochemical tools has provided a unique methodology to identify sites of biological methylation and improve our fundamental understanding of methylation in cellular processes.  The largest impact of this project has been the development of new collaborations with Emory University and The Ohio State University to investigate RNA methyltransferases.  Preliminary evidence indicates the RNA methyltransferases studied to date not only utilize the SAM analogs generated in this project but can be exploited to understand fundamental biochemical questions.  We are actively seeking answer to understand these enzyme structures and functions by combining traditional biochemistry, genetics, and structural biology methods.

Additionally, this research has allowed for undergraduate and graduate students to engage in collaborative scholarship at the interface between chemistry and biology. Over the course of the project, a total of 4 graduate students have been trained, each working towards four distinct objectives. Moreover, a total of 11 undergraduate students have worked on the project and have focused on sub-objectives conducting biochemical reactions, exploring bioanalytical methods, and preparing N-mustard analogs using traditional organic chemistry techiqes.  Students have not only presented their work at Wake Forest symposia, but have also presented (oral and poster) at national and international conferences.

Finally, this project has allowed me to expand my collaborative efforts with Kaleideum North (the science center and environmental park of Forsyth county), to share my scientific interests with the community. Activities developed included exposing children to chemistry at the museum through food-based experiments. This has been largely facilitated in conjunction with an upper-level majors special topics course, Kitchen Chemistry, that I developed and have taught twice during this project. More importantly, this course included a unique project that was designed for the students to develop and implement an experinece for the visitors at the museum to engage in chemistry through hands-on food demonstrations. This project not only gave Wake Forest students the opportunity to be creative, but it allowed them to translate academic language and knowledge about food and cooking to non-scientists.
